Package de.dfki.lt.hfc.operators

  • Class Summary 
    Class Description
    CardinalityNotEqual
    CardinalityNotEqual returns only those subject-predicate-object triples which consist of a predicate that violates its cardinality description (if there is any; see example below); note that the open-world assumption together with the (non-)existence of owl:sameAs and owl:differentFrom axioms MUST be taken into consideration when using the below implementation of this predicate EXAMPLE + assumes a closed-world (total knowledge) + only datatype properties are taken into account + object properties must also employ sameAs & differentFrom ONTOLOGY (RBox) q rdf:type owl:DatatypeProperty _:b1 rdf:type owl:Restriction _:b1 owl:onProperty q _:b1 owl:cardinality "1"^^xsd:int r rdf:type owl:DatatypeProperty _:b2 rdf:type owl:Restriction _:b2 owl:onProperty r _:b2 owl:cardinality "1"^^xsd:int ONTOLOGY (ABox) foo q 10 foo q 20 foo r 30 bar q 40 bar r 50 ENTAILMENT RULE ?p rdf:type owl:DatatypeProperty ?r owl:onProperty ?p ?r owl:cardinality ?c ?s ?p ?o -> ?s rdf:type owl:Nothing
    Concatenate
    Concatenate is an implementation of the concatenate operator that takes an arbitrary number of arguments (hopefully strings, represented through ids = positive ints) and returns an object that encapsulates the concatenation of the input strings (again an int); note that the input argument strings must be given as an array (of ints)
    DTIntersectionNotEmpty
    checks whether the intersection of two temporal intervals whose starting and ending time is given by two XSD dateTime instants is empty or not; we do not check whether apply() is given exactly four arguments
    DTLess
    checks whether the first argument is less than the second argument; arguments are assumed to be of type XsdDateTime;
    DTLessEqual
    checks whether the first argument is less or equal than the second argument; arguments are assumed to be of type XsdDateTime;
    DTMax2
    computes the maximum of the two (2) arguments given to apply(); we do NOT check whether there are less than or more than two arguments; arguments are assumed to be of type ; returns the maximal dateTime instant
    DTMin2
    computes the minimum of the two (2) arguments given to apply(); we do NOT check whether there are less than or more than two arguments; arguments are assumed to be of type ; returns the minimal dateTime instant
    EquivalentClassAction
    an EquivalentClassAction call can be used for replacing an equivalentClass RHS pattern in a rule; this might happen when equivalence class reduction is turned on
    EquivalentClassTest
    an EquivalentClassTest call can be used for replacing an equivalentClass LHS pattern in a rule; this might happen when equivalence class reduction is turned on
    EquivalentPropertyAction
    an EquivalentPropertyAction call can be used for replacing an equivalentProperty RHS pattern in a rule; this might happen when equivalence class reduction is turned on
    EquivalentPropertyTest
    an EquivalentPropertyTest call can be used for replacing an equivalentProperty LHS pattern in a rule; this might happen when equivalence class reduction is turned on
    FDecrement
    computes the decrement of the single argument given to apply(); argument is assumed to be an xsd:float; returns a representation of the new float
    FDifference
    computes the difference of the two arguments given to apply(); arguments are assumed to be xsd:floats; returns a representation of the new float
    FEqual
    checks whether the first argument is equal to the second argument; arguments are assumed to be numbers of type xsd:float
    FGreater
    checks whether the first argument is greater than the second argument; arguments are assumed to be xsd:floats;
    FGreaterEqual
    checks whether the first argument is greater or equal than the second argument; arguments are assumed to be xsd:floats;
    FIncrement
    computes the increment of the single argument given to apply(); argument is assumed to be an xsd:float; returns a representation of the new float
    FLess
    checks whether the first argument is less than the second argument; arguments are assumed to be xsd:floats;
    FLessEqual
    checks whether the first argument is less or equal than the second argument; arguments are assumed to be xsd:floats;
    FMax
    computes the maximum of the arguments given to apply(); arguments are assumed to be xsd:floats; returns the maximal float
    FMin
    computes the minimum of the arguments given to apply(); arguments are assumed to be xsd:floats; returns the minimal float
    FNotEqual
    checks whether the first argument is not equal to the second argument; arguments are assumed to be numbers of type xsd:float
    FProduct
    computes the product of the arguments given to apply(); arguments are assumed to be xsd:floats; returns a representation of the new float
    FQuotient
    computes the quotient of the two arguments given to apply(); arguments are assumed to be xsd:floats; returns a representation of the new float
    FSum
    computes the sum of the arguments given to apply(); arguments are assumed to be xsd:floats; returns a representation of the new float
    GetDateTime
    returns the current time encoded as an XsdDateTime object, internally represented by a collection of ints and a float
    GetLongTime
    returns the current time encoded as an xsd:long
    IDecrement
    computes the decrement of the single argument given to apply(); argument is assumed to be an xsd:int; returns a representation of the new int
    IDifference
    computes the difference of the two arguments given to apply(); arguments are assumed to be xsd:ints; returns a representation of the new int
    IEqual
    checks whether the first argument is equal to the second argument; arguments are assumed to be numbers of type xsd:int
    IGreater
    checks whether the first argument is greater than the second argument; arguments are assumed to be xsd:ints;
    IGreaterEqual
    checks whether the first argument is greater or equal than the second argument; arguments are assumed to be xsd:ints;
    IIncrement
    computes the increment of the single argument given to apply(); argument is assumed to be an xsd:int; returns a representation of the new int
    IIntersectionNotEmpty
    checks whether the intersection of two temporal intervals whose starting and ending time is given by two XSD ints is empty or not; we do not check whether apply() is given exactly four arguments
    ILess
    checks whether the first argument is less than the second argument; arguments are assumed to be xsd:ints;
    ILessEqual
    checks whether the first argument is less or equal than the second argument; arguments are assumed to be xsd:ints;
    IMax
    computes the maximum of the arguments given to apply(); arguments are assumed to be xsd:ints; returns the maximal int
    IMax2
    computes the maximum of the two (2) arguments given to apply(); we do NOT check whether there are less than or more than two arguments; arguments are assumed to be of type ; returns the maximal int
    IMin
    computes the minimum of the arguments given to apply(); arguments are assumed to be xsd:ints; returns the minimal int
    IMin2
    computes the minimum of the two (2) arguments given to apply(); we do NOT check whether there are less than or more than two arguments; arguments are assumed to be of type ; returns the minimal int
    INotEqual
    checks whether the first argument is not equal to the second argument; arguments are assumed to be numbers of type xsd:int
    IntStringToBoolean
    converts its single argument (which is assumed to be the internal representation of a string) into the internal representation of a Boolean value, where "0" is interpreted as the "false" value and everything else as "true" returns the representation of the new boolean
    IProduct
    computes the product of the arguments given to apply(); arguments are assumed to be xsd:ints; returns a representation of the new int
    IQuotient
    computes the quotient of the two arguments given to apply(); arguments are assumed to be xsd:ints; returns a representation of the new int -- note that the remainder is lost!
    IsAtom
    checks whether the first argument given to IsAtom is an XSD atom
    IsBlankNode
    checks whether the first argument given to IsBlankNode is a blank node
    IsNotSubtypeOf
    IsNotSubtypeOf checks whether the two arguments given to apply() are NOT standing in a subtype relation: arg1 arg2 IsNotSubtypeOf addresses the open-world nature of OWL: arg1 !(arg1 <= arg2) <==> (arg1 > arg2) | (arg1 & arg2 = bottom) <==> ((arg1 != arg2) & (arg2 arg1)) | (arg1 arg2)
    ISum
    computes the sum of the arguments given to apply(); arguments are assumed to be xsd:ints; returns a representation of the new int
    IsUri
    checks whether the first argument given to IsUri is a URI
    LDecrement
    computes the decrement of the single argument given to apply(); argument is assumed to be an xsd:long; returns a representation of the new long
    LDifference
    computes the difference of the two arguments given to apply(); arguments are assumed to be of type xsd:long; returns a representation of the new long
    LEqual
    checks whether the first argument is equal to the second argument; arguments are assumed to be numbers of type xsd:long
    LGreater
    checks whether the first argument is greater than the second argument; arguments are assumed to be xsd:longs;
    LGreaterEqual
    checks whether the first argument is greater than the second argument; arguments are assumed to be xsd:longs;
    LIncrement
    computes the decrement of the single argument given to apply(); argument is assumed to be an xsd:long; returns a representation of the new long
    LIntersectionNotEmpty
    checks whether the intersection of two temporal intervals whose starting and ending time is given by two XSD longs is empty or not; we do not check whether apply() is given exactly four arguments
    LLess
    checks whether the first argument is greater than the second argument; arguments are assumed to be xsd:longs;
    LLessEqual
    checks whether the first argument is greater than the second argument; arguments are assumed to be xsd:longs;
    LMax
    computes the maximum of the arguments given to apply(); arguments are assumed to be of type xsd:long; returns the maximal long
    LMax2
    computes the maximum of the two (2) arguments given to apply(); we do NOT check whether there are less than or more than two arguments; arguments are assumed to be of type ; returns the maximal long
    LMin
    computes the minimum of the arguments given to apply(); arguments are assumed to be of type xsd:long; returns the minimal long
    LMin2
    computes the minimum of the two (2) arguments given to apply(); we do NOT check whether there are less than or more than two arguments; arguments are assumed to be of type ; returns the minimal long
    LNotEqual
    checks whether the first argument is not equal to the second argument; arguments are assumed to be numbers of type xsd:long
    LProduct
    computes the product of the arguments given to apply(); arguments are assumed to be of type xsd:long; returns a representation of the new long
    LQuotient
    computes the difference of the two arguments given to apply(); arguments are assumed to be of type xsd:long; returns a representation of the new long
    LSum
    computes the product of the arguments given to apply(); arguments are assumed to be of type xsd:long; returns a representation of the new long
    MakeBlankNode
    given an arbitrary number of input args (int ids) encoding URIs, blank nodes, or XSD atoms, this operator deterministically generates a new blank node by appending the external representation of the args
    MakeUri
    given an arbitrary number of input args (int ids), encoding objects of XSD type string, this operator deterministically generates an URI by appending the args into a new string that is `surrounded' by '<' and `>'
    NoSubClassOf
    NoSubClassOf checks whether the tuple store does NOT _contain_ a rdfs:subClassOf statement between the two arguments given to apply() NOTE: this predicate does in fact check for the _non-existence_ of information, thus when used during forward chaining in a rule (e.g., integrity constraint) might lead to wrong information -- thus it is important to properly apply the constraint at the 'right' time EXAMPLE: $domainRestrictionViolated ?p ?d ?s ?p ?o ?s ?t -> ?s
    NoValue
    NoValue checks whether a specific tuple or a partial description of a tuple (potentially describing several tuples) exist in the tuple store; variables have already been replaced by their bindings, thus we are dealing with positive ints; in order to address a partial description, we do allow a special don't care value "*" that is internally represented by FunctionalOperator.UNBOUND; note that the length of args as given to apply() indicates that we are searching for tuples of EXACTLY this length, thus (1) NoValue ?s ?p ?o (2) NoValue ?s "Hi"^^ (3) NoValue * * * (4) NoValue ?s ?p * (5) NoValue ?s * "42" (6) NoValue ?s * * each pattern always looks for _triples_; even pattern (3) makes sense, since it checks for the (non)existence of triples in the tuple store -- remember, we are not forced to deal with tuples of length three only
    PrintContent
    prints the content of the binding tables given to apply() to standard out
    PrintFalse
    prints the arguments given to apply() to standard out
    PrintSize
    prints the size of the arguments (binding tables) given to apply() to standard out
    PrintTrue
    prints the arguments given to apply() to standard out
    SameAsAction
    a SameAsAction call can be used for replacing a sameAs RHS pattern in a rule; this might happen when equivalence class reduction is turned on
    SameAsTest
    a SameAsTest call can be used for replacing a sameAs LHS pattern in a rule; this might happen when equivalence class reduction is turned on
    UDTLess
    checks whether the first argument is less than the second argument; arguments are assumed to be of type XsdUDateTime;
